revisions.rev:
{{About|figure skating coach|the former head coach of the [[Toronto Maple Leafs|Toronto St. Patricks]]|Frank Carroll (ice hockey)}} {{Infobox figure skater |name= Frank Carroll |image= Evan Lysacek and Frank Carroll 2007-2008 GPF.jpg |caption= Carroll with student [[Evan Lysacek]] at the 2007-2008 Grand Prix Final |country= [[United States of America|United States]] |fullname = Francis M. Carroll |birth_date= July 1938<ref name="RCohen021910"/><ref name="LAT021910"/> |birth_place= [[Worcester, Massachusetts]] |death_date= |residence= [[California]] |height= |partner= |formerpartner= |coach= |formercoach= [[Maribel Vinson]] |choreographer= |formerchoreographer= |skating club= |retired= }} '''Francis M. "Frank" Carroll'''<ref name="HC1960"/> (born March 1939,<ref name="RCohen021910"/><ref name="LAT021910"/> [[Worcester, Massachusetts]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[figure skating]] [[Coach (sport)|coach]] and former competitive skater. He has coached three skaters to win the [[World Figure Skating Championships]]: [[Linda Fratianne]], [[Michelle Kwan]], and [[Evan Lysacek]].<ref name=bwilner/> His pupil, [[Evan Lysacek]] won the men's Olympic gold medal in 2010 at Vancouver.
He has been inducted into the [[World Figure Skating Hall of Fame]] and the [[United States Figure Skating Hall of Fame]] and was the 1997 [[USOC Coach of the Year|Olympic Coach of the Year]].
==Competitive and professional career== Carroll grew up in [[Worcester, Massachusetts]]. When he was in his early teens, a skating rink opened in his neighborhood and he began skating,<ref name="talking"/> interested by the combination of artistry and athleticism.<ref name=icebreaker/> After graduating from the [[College of the Holy Cross]] in 1960 with a B.S. in Sociology,<ref name="HC1960"/><ref name=direction/> Carroll eventually moved to [[Winchester, Massachusetts]] and lived with his coach [[Maribel Vinson Owen]] and her daughters on weekends.<ref name="talking"/>
Carroll won the bronze medal on the junior level at the 1959 [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. Championships]].<ref name=chsc/> He won the silver medal on the junior level at the 1960 U.S. Championships behind [[Douglas Ramsay]].<ref name=frozen/> Carroll turned professional after that and was skating with the [[Ice Follies]] at the time of the [[Sabena Flight 548]] crash.<ref name=smilton/>
Carroll skated with the Ice Follies until 1964. He was accepted to law school at the [[University of San Francisco]], but chose to pursue acting.<ref name="talking"/> He appeared in the background of several beach films, including [[The Loved One (film)|The Loved One]].<ref name="talking"/> He began coaching on the side to support himself and eventually decided to coach full-time. His most notable students have been [[Linda Fratianne]], [[Michelle Kwan]] and [[Evan Lysacek]]. He is the current coach of the 2008 National Champion, [[Mirai Nagasu]], who placed 4th at the 2010 Olympics. He was the head coach for the [[Toyota Sports Center]] in [[El Segundo, California]]. In 2011, he began coaching at a newly built rink in Palm Springs, one of his homes since the 1970s.<ref name=numbers/><ref name=icebreaker/>
==Results== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Event ! 1959 ! 1960 |- | [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. Championships]] || align="center" bgcolor="cc9966" | 3rd J. || align="center" bgcolor="silver" | 2nd J. |} * J = Junior level
==Coaching career== Carroll's current and former students include: <!-- alphabetized list --> *[[Nicole Bobek]] *[[Christopher Bowman]].<ref name=moment/> Coached him to the U.S. National title and a World silver medal in 1989 and to a World Bronze medal in 1990. *[[Tiffany Chin]]. Coached her to two World bronze medals. *[[Ellie Kawamura]]. *[[Mark Cockerell]]. *[[Silvia Fontana]]<ref>{{isu name | id = 00001684 | name = Silvia Fontana}}</ref> *[[Linda Fratianne]].<ref name=icebreaker/> Coached her to two World Championships and to an Olympic silver medal in 1980.<ref name=moment/> *[[Timothy Goebel]]. Coached him to the 2002 and 2003 World silver medals and the 2002 Olympic bronze medal. Carroll ended his coaching relationship with Goebel in November 2004 following the [[2004 NHK Trophy]]<ref name=goebel/> * [[Kristiene Gong]].<ref>{{isu name | id= 00011960 | name=Kristiene Gong}}</ref> *[[Danielle Kahle]].<ref>{{isu name | id= 00006299 | name=Danielle Kahle}}</ref> *[[Jennifer Kirk]].<ref>{{isu name | id = 00004245 | name=Jennifer Kirk}}</ref> *[[Carolina Kostner]].<ref>{{isu name | id= 00004864 | name=Carolina Kostner}}</ref> *[[Karen Kwan]]. *[[Michelle Kwan]]. He coached her to four World Championships and to an Olympic silver medal in 1998. In the fall of 2001, Kwan and Carroll decided to end their coaching relationship. In interviews, Kwan said she needed to "take responsibility" for her skating.<ref name=kwan/> *[[Beatrisa Liang]].<ref>{{isu name | id = 00005324 | name=Beatrisa Liang}}</ref> *[[Evan Lysacek]]. He coached him to a World Championship in 2009 and an Olympic gold medal in 2010.<ref name=journey/><ref name=isulysacek/> *[[Ye Bin Mok]]<ref>{{isu name | id = 00004249 | name= Ye Bin Mok}}</ref> *[[Daisuke Murakami (figure skater)|Daisuke Murakami]].<ref>{{isu name | id = 00007654 | name=Daisuke Murakami}}</ref> *[[Mirai Nagasu]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Nagasu leaves Wong, moves to Carroll | url = http://web.icenetwork.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20090520&content_id=4835608&vkey=ice_news | date = 20 May 2009 | accessdate = 21 May 2009 }}</ref> *[[Angela Nikodinov]].<ref>{{isu name | id= 00000158 | name = Angela Nikodinov}}</ref> *[[Denis Ten]].<ref>{{isu name | id= 00008858 | name = Denis Ten}}</ref>
He has coached skaters to win the [[World Figure Skating Championships]] during the era of [[compulsory figures]] (Fratianne), after compulsory figures (Kwan), and under the [[ISU Judging System]] (Lysacek). He also coached Lysacek to an Olympic gold medal.
Carroll was inducted into the [[United States Figure Skating Hall of Fame]] in 1996.<ref name=ifs090520/> He is the first figure skating coach to be named the [[USOC Coach of the Year|Olympic Coach of the Year]], which happened in 1997.
On March 6, 2007, it was announced that he was elected to the [[World Figure Skating Hall of Fame]].<ref name=ifs090520/> He was inducted on March 22, 2007 during the [[2007 World Figure Skating Championships]], between the original dance and the men's free skate.
